titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I leave Oxford with a strange sense of loneliness, almost as if I had been expelled. Everybody is kind enough, & I love every stone of the place, yet I do not belong to it, nor can I enter without an effort into its interests and ideals. There is no unhappier condition under which any man's life can be passed than that of remoteness from the common experiences: and that is precisely my unfortunate lot. At every turn I must be silent lest I should be either offensive or absurd. Exiled by no fault of my own from the normal life, social & intellectual, I might have gained a foothold in Oxford, & become in some sense intelligible to it, if I could have thrown myself into its ecclesiastical activities. But this became altogether impossible. The solitude grows ever more complete. The same fortune pursues me in the world outside Oxford. I do not share the general enthusiasms, nor am I intelligible to my contemporaries. Set in a chair of great authority I can command neither the confidence of colleagues, nor the loyalty of subordinates. It is probably the case that the experiences of youth are most keenly felt & most vividly appreciated in later life. Therefore the absence of happy & honourable experiences in youth is so grave a calamity. Old age must live on memories, as youth on hopes. And the quality of the memories goes far to determine the quality of old age.

I travelled by way of Leicester, Nottingham, Sheffield, York to Darlington where I was met by the car, & driven to Auckland.
